r
L. to bee adv
r
tized
t w

r

re
of the 14 of
m
r
ch w
ch
came to my hand
the 4 of this p
nt
I Rxd one from my
LL of
e Councell
of
e 15 of
e same moneth & an oth
r
to
e
g
na
l states
w
th
whom I have dealt as I hope in such ample &
sufficient maner as
e importance of these causes &
t credyt required
w
ch
eir LL gave unto mee, the coppie of
t w
ch
I proposed I have
sent
e LL herew
t
& likewise a l
re
to my LL. of
e Consell w
ch
I humbly
beseech y
ou
to p
nt
unto
em and yf y
ou
find yt expedient to recommend to
theyr furderance
e autority of this counsell yt is
t no dout w
ch
would
reduce
e goverment of
es contreys yf not to a
fect good state
yet assuredly to stay in order, as they should fynd by
e effect
to bee
much more tollerable. w
t
all yt would bee a meanes to cutt of
e credyt
of such among
e g
na
l states as take a speciall pride in contending
w
th
her
Ma
ty
I have had many charges from hence to deal w
th
e
states in
is cause & I have used earnest speeches to such effect as I
was willed, but because there hath nothing fallen owt upon theyr
careles answeres, yt is much to be douted that they take yt all for
no other but for a matter of course / althou yt were come to
t point
w
ch
yo
r
L. doth wishe
t
e g
na
l states could bee induced to a new
treaty & to put in oblivion all manner of former breaches on both
ides acknowledging theyr dew dett to her Ma
ty
, yet I am fully
swaded
they will de
t w
th
no oth
r
peaces of assurance th
e
they have don
alredy for the remborsement of her Hig
nes
charges. also theyr
publick Act for acknowledging theyr dett might be somewhat in show
in respect of sondry defalcations upon w
ch
yt is likely hereafter they
will insist, but unles her Ma
ty
were so possessed as shee ys of some
cautionary townes I see ev
r
y daie by theyr wrangling courses in
most mens causes that when they are not enclined to make satisfac
o
n
they will nev
r
want evasyons to frustrat theyr Actes, It wilbe a great
allegac
o
n among them when they come to [achount]
t her Ma
ties
assistance
was nev
r
kept complet. that
e musters and paiements have bin made
w
th
out theyr privity
t the 15 dead paies were nev
r
allowed by
e
Country &
e nomb
r
of absenc
ev
r
greater th
e
was to bee
mitted
w
th
divers oth
r
objections w
th
all thing
considered mighte be
ticularly
and very reasonably assured according to theyr sev
r
all natures, but I
have given th
e
hethertoo a g
na
l answear,
t her Ma
ty
notw
th
standing her
oft
e
and earnest sollicitac
o
n could nev
r
yet obtaine that
e
Councell of state
might be established in
eir full autority wh
r
by shee might orderly come
to
e notice of those disorders & w
th
all resolve to cast
e whole care of
reformac
o
n upon the sayd Councell to wh
o
by agreement betwene her Hig
nes
&
e contry yt doth only belong, The wrong
t hath bin don to her Ma
ti
& these provinces yn
t respect I have somewhat debated in this last
proposition, how yt may stand w
th
her Ma
tyes
surety to break w
th
these
contreys, as farr as I c
a
conceave submitting my opinion to yo
r
L.
correction, yt will very much depend up
o
e prospitous successe of
e
F
. King
affaires for othrwise yf the enemeyes forces should continew
in
e strength as they have bin heertofore I see not how they can w
th
stand
w
th
out
e help of her Ma
ty
for were yt so that
e generall meanes
fol.164v
of those Provinces being husbanded accordingly might ent
r
tain
some thousand
more in secret th
e
are heer at
is p
nt
, as I
think they are able, yet yf her Ma
ty
should forsake e Countrey
it is thought
t
e people would dispair, & fall up
o
a suddain
to accord w
th
e Enemey, where as now on
e oth
r
syde the
[.]
only name of her Ma
ty
the ennemeyes opinion of
e vallew of her
subjects, & therof his feare of new supplies in time of necessity
is a very great ayde though there were no other, neither ys yt so
that
e States heer doth not thoroly see into yt but yt ys supposed
among th
e
& sometymes given out,
t her Ma
ty
of necessity & in
regard of her own saffety must c
o
tinew theyr
tection, & thens
up
o
e occasyons,
t are offred in yo
r
L. l
re
I have sayd my opinion
w
ch
wheth
r
yt bee well or ill conceaved I trust yo
r
L. will afford
the best construction. Heer I hold yt requesyt to adv
r
tise yo
r
L
of a spetiall injury w
ch
ys offred her Ma
ty
by
e meanes of
M
r
Ortels
being in
England,
for yt seemeth by
e L
res
of her Hig
nes
& of my LL of
e Councell,
t hee ys reputed there an Agent for
e
g
na
l states of these countreys, &
t whatsoev
r
by word or by writing
by waie of answear or oth
r
wise ys deliv
r
ed unto him to be im
ted
to
e g
na
l states, or to
e Counsel of State of these contreys is
signified accordingly, howbeyt
e truth ys that hee ys agent onely
for
e
States of Holland
, & hath no deputac
o
n fr
o
any oth
r
province
& therfore maketh his dispatches not to
e Councell of States unles yt
bee upon spetiall requisition, & in some spetiall cause, but usually
to
Barnevelt
e advocat of
Holland
or to
e
ticular assembly
w
ch
doth not keepe correspondence w
th
e Councell of state but taketh
advantage of relating or concealing such matter of his l
res
as they
list themselves, by this meanes whatsoev
r
her Ma
ty
, My LL of
e
Counsell or any in theyr behalf hath deliv
r
ed unto him to bee dl
heer to
e g
na
l state of
e Contrey ys onely addressed to
e states of
Holland & by them either notified or suppressed or im
ted in such
measure as among
em selves is deemed convenient I do not dout
but by her Ma
ties
order ther hath bin many times many thing
communicated w
th
him about
e affaires of these contreys, w
ch
yf they
had bin published heer might have given
e state a great
satisfaction, but since my being in this place I c
a
not
rememb
r
above 3 or 4 l
res
t he hath written to
is Councell
I do not cast
e whole fault of this abuse up
o
M
r
Ortell him self
for he hath his comission. & entertainment fr
o
e states of Holland
& therefore bound to them onely, & besides yt should appeare
t hee
himself ys not privy to
is couvert kinde of dealing either in
Barnevelt or yn
e states of Holland. for in his last answer, to
a l
re
w
ch
hee sent to
e Councell of state, con
t
such matter as was
dl by
M
r
Wilkes
to theyr late demand
he maketh mention of former
answears sent unto th
e
about
e self same request
, w
ch
were nev
r
yet im
ted, but either kept back by
e Advocat or by
e assembly of
Holland, this manner of
ceeding hath bin used a long time
fol.165r
but unknowen to
e Councell heer, till yt came in question upon
his l
re
unto them, & upon
e coppie of
e Articles w
ch
yo
r
L.
send unto mee exhibited by M
r
Ortell yn
e name of
e g
na
l
states and apostilled by my LL of
e Counsell the 15 of m
r
che
w
ch
articles & apostilles though they conteyne such matter as
belongeth onely to
e conduct of
e counsell of State were never
opened yet unto them. whereby
e Counsell being ignorant what was
passed writ lately againe about
e self same affayres & this because
e g
na
ll states,
e Counsell of state & e states of Holland propose
theyr reasons a
te at sev
r
all times and yn divers meanes theyr
confused courses both p
nt
my LL of
e counsell to a great deale of
troble & occasy
o
many times that
e self same answers ar not
made to
e same propositions for
e redresse of this disorder
I have promysed this Councell w
ch
ys much agreived w
th
yt, to be
an humble sutor both in theyr behalf & myne owne that whensoev
r
M
r
Ortell shall sollicit any matter in
e name of
e g
na
l states
or of
e Counsell of state he may be charged there, upo
e [Rst]
of his answer to send yt directly & indirectly to those to whom
intended to be given & not to
e states of Holland w
ch
is sent
one province, wh
r
as his negotia
o
n doth concerne th
e
all, the
consyderac
o
n wherof & what ys convenient to be don up
o
yt I
referr unto yo
r
L. wisdome nothing douting but yf eith
r
in this point
or in any of
e former there by any thing worthy to be reported to my
LL of
e councell yt wilbe signified unto th
e
by yo
r
honorable
meanes / how well this state ys provided of forreine intelligence
yo
r
L. may conjecture yn
t it was more th
e
a moneth before wee
knew any certainty either by l
res
or otherwise of
e late battail in
France
whereof yo
r
L. l
re
to mee brought one of
e freshest report
for w
ch
I thank yo
r
L. very humbly, & for
e oth
r
point
of
e l
res
w
ch
being
very materiall & coming from yo
r
L. are both a great comfort
&
unto mee & a spetiall furderance to my service / astouching the
occurences heer there ys litell to be c
r
tified but
t
e enemy
practiseth to surprise
e towne of
Bergh
e
for he increaseth his forces
in those quarters & by common conjecture hath some intelligence in e Towne, it is not yet knowen nor suspected w
th
whom, but for
e governo
rs
assistance is making enquiry & for other needfull alterac
o
ns in the garrison
M
r
Gilpin
& oth
r
s ar sent thether. Yt doth appeer by one of those
l
res
w
ch
were deciphered by
Mons
r
S
t
Aldegond
t
e
K of Spain
doth purpose to get
e possession of
e Dukedome of
Cleave
for w
ch
e
p
nt
opportunity doth serve very fitly because
e Younge Prince is
distracted, & in a more pitifull state th
e
e father, Howebeit to prevent
his intention
e bett
r
, there are coppies of
e K
s
letters sent fr
o
hence
to
e Counsell of Cleve, to
e towne of
Westell
, w
ch
are both well
affected,
unto
& to theyr neibour princes / We have sertain intelligence
fr
o
Bruges,
t 3
0
regiments of Wallons being newly mutined
attempted to take a port of that Towne & were
tly entred, but by
the diligence of
e burgers, there were 50 of th
e
slaine, & the rest
repulsed. It is spok
e
heer in secrett
t
Co. Hollock
being highly
discontented w
th
the small regard
t is had of him by
e States
fol.165v
To my L. Treasurer 18 A
p
90
is fully resolved to take his leave of these countreys & to serve
the F
r
King. It is also said among some t seem to speak
up
o
knowledge, that yt is heer in p
nt
deliberac
o
n among
some principall persons to consitute
Co Maurice
Count of
Holland
& thus most humbly craving yo
r
L. pardon for
my tedious discowrses I take my humble leave.
from the Hage A
p
18. 90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho: Bodley.
